properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 2 at 2:20PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
properties.description:
A storm system will bring much colder temperatures, high winds,
and snow to the Land of Enchantment on Monday and Tuesday. Strong
to damaging southwest winds will arrive first, and impact areas
near and south of I-40 as well as the Chuska Mountains in western
New Mexico. Gusts between 50 and 60 mph are possible atop the
high terrain, tapering off Monday night. Windy conditions with
gusts upwards of 40 to 50 mph will also reach down to portions of
eastern New Mexico. Crosswinds will be a main concern for any high
profile vehicles.

Snow will favor northern and western New Mexico Monday afternoon
through Tuesday. The heaviest snow amounts are expected across the
northern mountains where up to 10 inches of snow is possible. A
dusting to an inch or two will be possible for lower elevations
of the west and north. Light snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches
will be possible through eastern New Mexico late Tuesday through
Tuesday night, with locally higher amounts of 6 to 8 inches atop
the Sacramento Mountains.

Temperatures will plummet across northwest New Mexico Monday
afternoon and through the remainder of the state Monday night and
early Tuesday morning as the front plunges southeastward. High
temperatures on Tuesday will struggle to reach the freezing mark
for many locations. Very cold temperatures will persist through
Wednesday as well.

Anyone planning travel in New Mexico Monday and Tuesday should be
prepared to encounter adverse weather conditions. Monitor NOAA
weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest
weather updates. For the latest New Mexico road conditions visit
nmroads.com or call 5-1-1.

NWSheadline: MAJOR CHANGES ON THE WAY MONDAY AND TUESDAY
